name: KING'S GAMBIT
idea: The most romantic opening in chess! White sacrifices the f2 pawn for rapid development and open lines against the Black King. The idea is simple: after 2...exf4, White plays Nf3 and Bc4, aiming at f7. Black can keep the pawn with ...g5 but the King becomes exposed. It's all-out attack vs solid defense. Fischer called it 'a decisive opening' - you either win or lose brilliantly!
errors_white: Playing Bc4 without Nf3: allows ...Qh4+ with check
Forgetting to castle: the King in the center is vulnerable
Pushing too many pawns: development is the key, not pawn advances
errors_black: Keeping the f4 pawn at all costs: development matters more
Playing ...g5 without preparation: h4 can become dangerous
Forgetting to develop: ...d5 and piece development are urgent
development: Nf3 is almost always the first move - defends and attacks, prepares 0-0
Bc4 targets f7 directly - the Bc4+Qb3/Qf3 battery is deadly
Sometimes 0-0 even while sacrificing material! Or Kf1-Kf2 if castling is compromised
Can go to f3 (attacks f7) or h5 (pressure on f7 and e5) depending on variation
Nc3 then Nd5 - the Knight on d5 is a monster
After fxe5 or if Black takes on g3, the Rook on f1 is devastating

traps.name: Muzio Gambit
traps.desc: After 3.Nf3 g5 4.Bc4 g4, White plays 5.0-0!! sacrificing the Knight! After gxf3 6.Qxf3 the attack on f7 is irresistible. AVOID (Black): Don't play ...g4 - prefer ...Bg7 or ...d6.

traps.name: Kieseritzky Trap
traps.desc: After 3.Nf3 g5 4.h4 g4 5.Ne5, if ...Nf6?? 6.Bc4! Threatens Nxf7 and Bxf7+. Double attack! AVOID (Black): Play ...d5! or ...Qe7 instead of ...Nf6 to block the diagonals.

traps.name: Declined Trap
traps.desc: 2...Bc5 (Declined) 3.Bc4!? Targets f7. If ...Nc6? 4.fxe5! Threatens Qh5 or Bxf7+. The Bc5 no longer defends anything! AVOID (Black): Play ...d6 or ...Nf6 to defend e5 before developing the Bishop.

variants.name: Classical Gambit Accepted
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 f2f4 e5f4 g1f3 g7g5 h2h4 g5g4 f3e5
variants.white_plan: The Ne5 attacks f7. After Bc4, the pressure is enormous. Possible sacrifices on f7 or g4 to open lines.
variants.black_plan: Defend f7 with ...Qe7 or counter-attack with ...d5! The g4 and f4 pawns can become strong in the endgame.

variants.name: Cunningham Defense
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 f2f4 e5f4 g1f3 f8e7 f1c4 e7h4 e1f1
variants.white_plan: The King goes to f1-f2 (without castling). White has the center and development. Attack with d4, Bxf4, Nc3.
variants.black_plan: The check on h4 forced Kf1 but the Bishop is exposed. Play ...d5! to open the game and activate the Bc8.

variants.name: Gambit Declined
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 f2f4 f8c5 g1f3 d7d6 b1c3 g8f6
variants.white_plan: Black refuses the gambit. Play fxe5 dxe5 and Bc4 to maintain pressure. The game is calmer.
variants.black_plan: Solid structure with ...d6 defending e5. Develop ...0-0, ...Nc6, ...Bg4 and look for ...d5 at the right moment.
